Are there then benefits to be had from the product over and above those that are around. There are other things like the SGLT-2 Dapoglyphozen that is quite high risk. It is a novel mechanism, but potentially a high reward. And you can go back into our Phase II and Phase I and see a balance of those.

And then your question around patent losses and what do the next few years look like. I mean we recognize there are dates out there when we will lose exclusivity. They will vary from place to place. But you know, obviously we lose our opportunity to grow those. That's why you said how do we as a management team look at it. We are very, very focused on getting our business to operate as efficiently as we possibly can, and bringing as many products and projects through as we possibly can. We are looking for late stage licensing opportunities to bring in. We think we've got a very, very strong commercial organization globally. It's certainly one of the -- in each of the markets or regions we operate, it's one of the fastest growing -- we have one of the fastest growing businesses on the back of our older products. So our goal is to get as many products into our pipeline and into the bags of our people as we can, and recognize we are going to lose exclusivity on some of these things, and figure out on a time-by-time basis how to do deal with it. Want to add to that? Good. Please, Alex.

Alexandra Hauber from JPMorgan. Two questions, firstly on the restructuring program, I'm just wondering whether with this restructuring program coming up, whether you think you can at least protect your 2009 earnings base for another two years, or whether you can even grow that? And looking at your head count chart, the incremental head count reduction, do you expect sort of a similar recycling rate, as in you are going to have 70% new positions and 30% net benefit? And the second question is again on the emerging markets, I mean so far the feedback we've got from the companies has been pretty consistent that there is no impact, but I'm just -- no impact yet from the economic crisis -- but I'm just wondering how much do you really have your finger at the pulse in terms of what's going on, because I would assume you ship into some channel and then it takes some time before you get the feedback from those channels. If there is really a slowdown, how quickly will you realize?
Okay. Well, that's good. Simon, can I ask you about the restructuring, the head count and net benefit, and how you look at that?

Yes, certainly. I mean we're not -- we haven't sort of provided aggregate guidance on earnings beyond 2009. You won't expect me to do so. In terms of the impact of the restructuring program, you saw that we have reduced the number of positions by 8,000. You saw that we reinvested 2,300 into emerging markets, and that's a theme that we'll – an area we will continue to invest. You did see a significant step-up of 3,000, which was associated with the acquisition of MedImmune and then some expansion of MedImmune. So, if you look forward, we would except to see a rather larger net incremental impact then you saw in the first 8,000.
Bruno, over to you, then, on emerging markets, how quickly you'd except to see something?

We are not saying there will be no impact. There will be an impact in these markets, which have been growing, as I mentioned at 12%, maybe growing this year and next year at a rate which would be lower than that, maybe 6, 7%. But that will be – or 7 or 8 if you want -- but that will be significantly better than what we observe in the U.S. and in Europe -- significantly better.
Second point, what we are saying is that we are well positioned in this market to still deliver a very strong performance.

Coming back to China, the pharmaceutical market in China may be growing this year less quickly than it used to grow, but we are waiting for this listing on major products, and that will give us, even in the context of the market, which will be growing at a rate lower than it is usually, still a very good perspective. So, the market is likely -- the growth rates of this market are likely to decrease somewhat, for sure. We are saying that they will be still attractive, and that we are, in this context, well positioned.

Okay good, I want to respect everybody's time, so what I'll do is stop here, but I just thought I would do a quick summary to say, we turned in a solid performance in 2008 with earnings per share growing faster than sales. We're driving efficiency and productivity throughout the organization, and improving our operating margins. At the same time, we are making investments that are vital to our long-term performance in emerging markets and in R&D. But I think as you heard from us and know yourselves, market conditions have never been tougher than they are today. The contraction of GDP in emerging markets as well as the U.S. and Western Europe is going to change the environment for our business, and we just have to deal with it.

I think our performance targets reflect what we believe is the relative resilience of our business, especially compared to other industrial sectors, and it won't be easy to deal with, but -- from my perspective -- but I think the actions that we've taken over the last several have positioned us well. We have driven more than 20% compound growth in earnings and dividends per share. I think we have created an operating and financial strength that should allow us to navigate what I believe will be some pretty choppy waters ahead. But we need to execute our plans, we need to deliver on the targets we've set. We've been able to do that so far, and we are committed more so than ever to doing it again.

And in closing, I just want to say a few words to mark John's retirement. As I've said before, innovative research and development is the heart and the life blood of our company, and John has been at the heart of our research and development organization and led real change that has made a difference in the shape of our pipeline, and the position we find ourselves in today. As he signs off on his last set of results here, I would just like to take this time to thank him for his leadership, for his friendship, which has been great, and his contribution to this company, which has been over 34 years in the making and he has worked both in the commercial, the R&D space. He's worked all over the company. He is leaving the function in good hands, but I want you all to know we'll miss John's presence in our executive room as well as in the board room.

So that brings us to the end of our presentation today. I thank you all, and as I said, we will be around to take on questions. I know I cut off the end of Alex's question. We will get back to her and others. So thank you very much.
